title: An overview of smovie
text: Consider \(n\) independent identically distributed random variables \(X_1, \ldots, X_n\), mean \(\mu\) finite variance \(\sigma^2\). Let \(\bar{X} = (1/ n) \sum_{=1}^n X_i\). (classical) Central limit theorem (CLT) states \(n \rightarrow \infty\) \(\sqrt{n}(\bar{X} - \mu) / \sigma\) converges distribution standard normal N(0, 1) distribution. Therefore, mean sufficiently large number variables approximately N(\(\mu, \sigma^2/n\)) distribution. function clt can used illustrate convergence distribution sample mean normal limit. Several continuous discrete distributions underlying variables available. buttons change value \(n\) simulate another sample size \(n\). simulations progress histogram sample means can compared normal approximation sampling distribution.
code: clt(distn = "exponential") clt(distn = "poisson")

what: Central Limit Theorem for sample quantiles
title: An overview of smovie
text: similar limit theorem holds sample quantiles. Suppose interested limiting distribution \(100p\%\) sample quantile independent identically distributed random variables, probability density function \(f\) \(100p\%\) quantile \(\xi(p)\). limiting distribution normal mean \(\xi(p)\) standard deviation \(\sqrt{p(1-p)} / n f(\xi(p))\), provided \(f(\xi(p))\) positive. See Lehman (1999) details. function cltq illustrates theorem, based samples gamma(2, 1) distribution.
code: cltq(distn = "gamma")

title: An overview of smovie
text: Extremal Types Theorem rather like CLT applied sample maximum instead sample mean. Loosely speaking, states , many situations, maximum large number \(n\) independent random variables approximately Generalized Extreme Value (GEV) distribution shape parameter \(\xi\). See Coles (2001) introductory account extreme value theory. function ett can used illustrate convergence distribution sample maximum GEV limit. Several continuous distributions underlying variables available corresponding different values limiting shape parameter \(\xi\). ett works essentially way clt except exact sampling distribution sample maximum also displayed.
code: ett(distn = "exponential")

title: An overview of smovie
text: Two movies illustrate key concepts hypothesis testing. wws compares three test statistics (Wald, Wilks Score) based log-likelihood. See Azzalini (1996) details. shypo illustrates concepts type type II errors, using example test simple hypothesis mean, general alternative, based random sample normal distribution known variance.

what: Wald, Wilks and Score test statistics
title: An overview of smovie
text: function wws shows differing ways three test statistics measure distance maximum likelihood estimate scalar parameter \(\theta\) value \(\theta_0\) null hypothesis. buttons change value \(\theta_0\), select test statistic display add values test statistics associated \(p\)-values test null hypothesis \(\theta = \theta_0\). example based sample binomial(\(20, \theta\)) distribution 7 successes 13 failures observed. example based normal distribution also available. may also specify log-likelihood.
code: wws(theta0 = 0.5, model = "binom", data = c(7, 13))

what: Testing a simple hypothesis: normally distributed variables
title: An overview of smovie
text: Consider random sample \(X_1, \ldots, X_n\) normal distribution unknown mean \(\mu\) known variance \(\sigma^2\). test null hypothesis \(H_0: \mu = \mu_0\) alternative \(H_1: \mu = \mu_1\), \(\mu_1 > \mu_0\). Let \(\bar{X} = (1/n) \sum_{=1}^n X_i\). reject null hypothesis \(\bar{X} > \). type error \(\alpha\) = \(P\)(reject \(H_0\) | \(H_0\) true). type II error \(\beta\) = \(P\)(don’t reject \(H_0\) | \(H_1\) true). function shypo creates plots normal pdfs \(H_0\) \(H_1\) type II errors function critical value \(\). Buttons used change values \(n\), \(\), \(\mu_0\), \(\mu_1 - \mu_0\) (effect size eff) population standard deviation \(\sigma\), order observe effects \(\alpha\) \(\beta\). Also included two radio buttons. One sets automatically value \(\) target type error equal achieved. sets automatically combination \(\) (integer) \(n\) target type error target_alpha type II error target_beta achieved bettered.
code: # 1. Change a (for fixed n) to achieve alpha <= 0.05 # 2. Change a and n to achieve alpha <= 0.05 and beta <= 0.1 shypo(mu0 = 0, eff = 5, n = 16, a = 2.3, delta_a = 0.01)

title: Some Movies to Illustrate Concepts in Statistics
text: smovie package provides movies help students understand statistical concepts. rpanel package used create interactive plots move illustrate key statistical ideas methods. movies cover topics probability distributions; sampling distributions mean (central limit theorem), median, maximum (extremal types theorem) (Fisher transformation ) correlation coefficient; simple linear regression; hypothesis testing.

code: wws(theta0 = 0.5)

title: Wald, Wilks and Score tests — wws
code: # N(theta, 1) example, test statistics equivalent wws(theta0 = 0.8)  # binomial(20, theta) example, test statistics similar wws(theta0 = 0.5, model = "binom")  # binomial(20, theta) example, test statistic rather different # for theta0 distant from theta_mle wws(theta0 = 0.9, model = "binom", data = c(19, 1), theta_range = c(0.1, 0.99))  # binomial(2000, theta) example, test statistics very similar wws(theta0 = 0.5, model = "binom", data = c(1000, 1000))  set.seed(47) x <- rnorm(10) wws(theta0 = 0.2, model = "norm", theta_range = c(-1, 1))  # Log-likelihood for a binomial experiment (up to an additive constant) bin_loglik <- function(p, n_success, n_failure) {   return(n_success * log(p) + n_failure * log(1 - p)) }  wws(loglik = bin_loglik, theta0 = 0.5, theta_range = c(0.1, 0.7),     theta_mle = 7 / 20, n_success = 7, n_failure = 13)  bin_alg_score <- function(p, n_success, n_failure) {   return(n_success / p - n_failure / (1 - p)) } bin_alg_obs_info <- function(p, n_success, n_failure) {   return(n_success / p ^ 2 + n_failure / (1 - p) ^ 2) } wws(loglik = bin_loglik, theta0 = 0.5, theta_range = c(0.1, 0.7),     theta_mle = 7 / 20, n_success = 7, n_failure = 13,     alg_score = bin_alg_score, alg_obs_info = bin_alg_obs_info)
